Risk to client if caregiver isn’t coping (e.g. client will be abandoned as caregiver might leave home)?

What has been happening? What is most concerning? 
What is the caregiver’s relationship to the client?

If yes, explain.

What care has the caregiver been doing? 
For how long? 
Who else is involved with the client’s care at home?

Any change in the health condition?

Does the caller feel the symptoms are being managed well? If no, explain.

Is there worry about leaving the home? 
If yes, explain.

Is there anyone else there now? 
If no, is there someone to call?

Describe the feeling:
“Tell me what has been happening?”

How distressing is this symptom?0 (not distressing) - 10 (distressing)
"What is most difcult for you?
 Is this distress worse/ better/same as before?
Is this feeling constant or does it come and go?

Caller’s thoughts on what is happening? 
What would they like to see happen?

Review Goals of Care
Are there any beliefs, views or feelings about this symptom that are important to keep in mind during treatment?

recommendations.content:
Try to determine the underlying reason that might be causing caregiver distress and being able to assess the severity of the distress. If the client is at undue risk, the need to call 911 may be required even if the client’s GOC are to remain at home.

Emergency situations

  • Suicidal ideation and/or plan in place – refer to Crisis Line 1-800-784-2433
  • Extreme caregiver agitation unable to assess over the phone resulting in high risk to client
  • Do you feel safe? Client becoming abusive and threatening to caregiver

Consider

  • Use a calming voice
  • Listen, don’t interrupt or rush
  • Allow silence, be mindful and use empathic listening
  • “What is concerning you most”
  • “Help me understand a bit more”
  • “You sound upset…”
  • “What I’m hearing is…do you feel that’s accurate?
  • “What have you done in the past that has been helpful?”
  • “How are you feeling now?”
  • If the short term plan is to get through till the morning ask: “Is there anyone you can call to come to the home?”
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

assessment_questions.question:
When did it begin? Has this happened before? 
How long did it last? 
How often does it occur?

What brings it on?
What makes it better? 
What makes it worse?

Physical: Pain, constipation (last BM), bladder retention (last voiding) hypoxia (breathing rates and pattern, SOB etc.), infection (fever), organ failure (cognition etc.), when did the client last eat/drink?
Medication: Any recent change after medication?
Psychosocial: Personal suffering, existential anguish, interpersonal conflict, worry, grief, spiritual distress
Neurological/Other: Delirium of any cause, history of - dementia, anxiety disorder, psychosis etc.

Imminently Dying (Terminal Restlessness): 
Select present combinations with altered and declining state of consciousness

Are there any other symptoms (e.g. muscle twitching, jerking, fidgeting, yelling, moaning, tossing and turning, crying, despondent)?
If yes, explain.

How severe is this symptom?
0 (no pain) – 10 (severe)
Right now? At worst? On average? 
How distressing is this symptom?

Are there any other symptom(s) that accompany this symptom? If yes, explain.
Does the client know what day/month/year it is, where they are, what is their full name?

Current medications/treatments? 
Medications taken in the past 24hrs?
How effective are these? 
What have you tried in the past?

Are non-prescription treatments, herbal remedies, or traditional healing practices being used? 
How effective are these? 
Any side effects? 
What was tried in the past? 
Any concerns about side effects or cost?

What do you believe is causing this symptom? 
How is it affecting you and/or your family? 
What is most concerning to you?

What overall goals do we need to keep in mind as we manage this symptom? 
What is your acceptable level for this symptom (0-10)? Are there any beliefs, views or feelings about this symptom that are important to you and your family?

recommendations.content:
Goals of Care: If symptom cannot be managed, would the client/family consider going to hospital for further investigation and/or treatment?

It is important to try and identify the possible underlying etiology prior to making any recommendations. Interventions will then be based on assessment of the current overall situation. E.g. infection, constipation, medications, pain, etc.

Recommendations will be based on Goals of Care and family/caregiver’s ability to manage care in the home.

If a delirium is suspected: This may be reversible with investigation and treatment dependent on Goals of Care

  • Review PRISM Interventions (see Resources).
  • Promote one-to-one observation to maintain safety, reduce fear, and support re-orientation.
  • Provide anticipatory guidance on what to expect. Normalize to reduce distress.
  • Provide guidance on how to interact with clients: gentle reassurance, not to argue, use of a calm voice and presence.
  • Sometimes clients may act out of character which can cause distress to the family. Explain that delirium symptoms are due to illness, are common, and can fluctuate.
  • Explain that delirium becomes less reversible near end of life.
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

recommendations.content: Review medications with caregiver. Advise which medications to give based on current orders.

recommendations.content:
Goals of Care: If symptom cannot be managed, would the client/family consider going to hospital for further investigation and/or treatment?

It is important to try and identify the possible underlying etiology prior to making any recommendations. Review current bowel care plan

May require transfer to acute care depending on Goals of Care

  • Bowel Obstruction: severe abdominal pain, abdominal swelling, vomiting, not passing gas

Interventions

  • Increase and monitor fluids, dietary fibre, and physical activity, as tolerated.
  • Wheat bran, dates and prunes improve bowel function, as tolerated.
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

recommendations.content:
Review medications with caregiver. Advise which medications to give based on current orders.

  • If bowel obstruction is not indicated and bowels have not moved for more than 3 days, increase bowel medications according to protocol and physician orders
  • When opioids are started, prophylactic laxatives are usually required, and should be continued for the duration of opioid use
  • Sennosides may be the most useful single laxative when an opioid is prescribed
  • A combination of a stimulant (e.g., sennosides), plus an osmotic laxative to moisturize and to soften stool (e.g., lactulose or polyethylene glycol (PEG)) may be required, particularly for opioid-induced constipation
recommendations.title: Pharmaceutical Interventions

Has a plan for a home death been discussed?

If no, have you considered one?

If no, do you need some assistance?

Able to manage with the current situation? 
If no, explain.

Is bereaved person threatening self-harm? 
Refer to Crisis Line.

assessment_questions.question: When did the client stop breathing?

What is the most important right now?  
Are there any beliefs, views or feelings about death that are important to keep in mind? 
Any required rituals or practices to complete?

recommendations.content:
Reassurance

  • Remind person that there is no immediate rush to call the funeral home
  • Assess for appropriate coping
  • Suggest that bereaved person call a friend or family member for support
  • Suggest that person make a cup of tea or sit quietly for a few moments
  • Provide empathy and psychosocial care as appropriate
  • Remind person that it is OK to touch the body
  • Suggest lowering the head of the bed and letting the body lie flat
  • Reassure caller and describe normal findings when witnessing death
  • Reassure caller about grief reactions – OK to cry, may feel a sense of relief, sadness etc.
  • Reassure that Home Care Nursing office will be contacted and that nurse will be in contact with person/family the next day
  • Suggest that person leave message for home support agency if applicable
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

resources.title: VCH Pamphlet “When Death is Close at Hand”

recommendations.content:
• Pulmonary: Infection, effusion, COPD/asthma, primary or metastatic tumour
  • Cardiac: CHF, CAD, arrhythmias, pericardial effusion.
  • Neuromuscular: ALS, CVA, MS
  • Other: Anxiety, fatigue/deconditioning, weakness, pain, severe anemia, infection,
  • Superior Vena Cava (SVC) obstruction: This is an emergency and requires prompt intervention
recommendations.title: Goals of Care

recommendations.content:
• Pulmonary: Infection, effusion, COPD/asthma, primary or metastatic tumour
  • Cardiac: CHF, CAD, arrhythmias, pericardial effusion.
  • Neuromuscular: ALS, CVA, MS
  • Other: Anxiety, fatigue/deconditioning, weakness, pain, severe anemia, infection,
  • Superior Vena Cava (SVC) obstruction: This is an emergency and requires prompt intervention
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

recommendations.content:
• Pulmonary: Infection, effusion, COPD/asthma, primary or metastatic tumour
  • Cardiac: CHF, CAD, arrhythmias, pericardial effusion.
  • Neuromuscular: ALS, CVA, MS
  • Other: Anxiety, fatigue/deconditioning, weakness, pain, severe anemia, infection,
  • Superior Vena Cava (SVC) obstruction: This is an emergency and requires prompt intervention
recommendations.title: Potential Causes of Dyspnea to keep in mind

recommendations.content:
Review medications with caregiver. Advise which medications to give based on current orders.

Suggestions based on current medication orders (PARIS) are:

  • Opioids – 1st line agent
  • Bronchodilators if has COPD or asthma may be helpful
  • Methotrimeprazine’s role limited to use only as a second line agent or in combination with an opioid when further opioid dose titration is contraindicated
  • A systematic review has found no efficacy evidence of benzodiazepines for the relief of breathlessness in clients with advanced cancer or COPD regardless of type of benzodiazepine, dose or route, nor for prevention of breakthrough dyspnea. Use benzodiazepines only as a second or third line agent when opioids and non-pharmacological measures have failed to control breathlessness.
  • If oxygen in the home, encourage to put on as ordered
recommendations.title: Pharmaceutical Interventions

recommendations.content:
Recommendations will be based on Goals of Care and family/caregiver’s ability to manage care in the home.

Review care plan and attached links to assist with recommendations and next steps.

  • Determine if caregiver has been previously doing the procedure(s) for client.
  • Determine what supplies are currently in the home.
  • Determine if caregiver has been taught what to do by the home care team if problems arise with current concern.
  • Determine if caregiver is capable to carry out any instructions given to manage the concern until home care nursing is able to visit.

Examples:

  • Dressing to wounds leaking: reinforce dressings with supplies or clean towel in home.
  • Blocked or bypassing catheter: if bypassing, use incontinence pads or towels until morning; if blocked, has caregiver been taught how to deflate balloon?
  • If S/C line is blocked, has caregiver been shown how to prefill syringes and administer S/C injections? If not, can caregiver be taught over phone or is client able to swallow orally (need to convert to oral dose).

** It’s important to remember that if a client is in distress with the concern addressed and the caregiver is NOT SAFELY ABLE TO MANAGE CARE than a transfer to acute care may be warranted. E.g. complete foley catheter blockage, S/C site reinsertion, pleurX drainage (abdominal or pleural) etc.**

recommendations.content:
Based on Goals of Care and the assessment will determine whether or not the client should be transferred to Emergency for investigation.

Try to determine the reason and etiology of the fall. Consider the following factors that contribute to the loss of balance:

  • Biological - advanced age, decreased mobility and balance, muscle weakness, visual impairment, acute or chronic illness and disability (i.e. cognitive impairment, stroke).
  • Behavioural - history of falls, poor nutrition and/or hydration, lack of physical activity, inappropriate footwear and clothing, and medications
  • Environmental - home hazards, lack of stair railings, loose rugs or other tripping hazards, lack of grab bars in the bathroom, poor lighting etc.
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

resources.title: Falls and Injury Prevention Guideline in the Community

Overall goals to keep in mind while managing this symptom? 
Are there any beliefs, views or feelings about this symptom that are important to keep in mind?
Are there any rituals or practices that you would like to complete?

recommendations.content:
Goals of Care: If symptom cannot be managed, would the client/family consider going to hospital for further investigation and/or treatment?

Prior to making any recommendation determine the following:

**Reassurance is very important if it appears that client is in last days/hours of life**

  1. Determine if the caregiver/family fully understand the current situation?
  2. After reviewing GOC are the client/family wishes for the client to remain at home at this time?
  3. Is there an EOL plan in place? Is there a Provincial No CPR in place? Is there a Notification of Expected Death form in place?
  4. Are there caregivers available and safely able to provide the necessary care to the client who may or may not have many symptoms over the next 24-hour period and possibly longer if needed? Does the caregiver or client feel too distressed to cope with the current situation? If there are children in the house do they have additional support?
  5. Do they know what to do when the client dies? Who to call? Care of the body?
  6. If the client is unable to swallow, are there medications prescribed/available that can be given subcutaneous, per rectum or under the tongue? Med kit in home? Is the caregiver capable of giving?
  7. What information does the caller have regarding the dying process?

Review the following with the caregiver:

  • DEHYDRATION Natural process; moist swabs, ice chips, lip balm
  • INCONTINENCE Pads, bed protection, sheets
  • SLEEPINESS/ UNRESPONSIVENESS ‘Being with’ is more important than ‘doing for’. Assume they can hear you. Maintain a calm and quiet environment with familiar people in attendance. Talk to and touch the client if that provides comfort.
  • CONFUSION Speak softly, clearly, truthfully. Keep the room lighting appropriate to the time of the day
  • DISCOLOURED/HOT/COLD LIMBS Circulation decreases and temperature control is irregular. Cool/warm client as appropriate.
  • GURGLING/RATTLING Saliva/mucus may collect in throat as swallow/cough reﬂex diminish. Client is usually unaware. Turn side-to-side, raise head on pillow.
  • IRREGULAR BREATHING Common, with intervals of seconds to minutes when no breathing occurs. May continue for minutes, hours or days.
  • PSYCHOSOCIAL Explore cultural or religious beliefs around illness and death. Explore the carer/family’s current emotional state (for example, fear, anxiety, anger and depression) and possible need to say good-bye or have final words with loved ones. Consider coping mechanisms and any risk for complex grief.
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

recommendations.content:
Goals of Care: If symptom cannot be managed, would the client/family consider going to hospital for further investigation and/or treatment?

It is important to try and identify the possible underlying etiology prior to making any recommendations.

Depending on the type of nausea, different anti-emetics are used. Refer to BC Palliative Symptom Practice guidelines.

Nausea/vomiting can be broken into five groups:

  • Gut causes
  • Chemical causes (this includes medications and electrolytes)
  • Raised intracranial pressure
  • Motion induced
  • Anxiety

Emergency situations that may require a transfer to acute care:

Gross hematemesis, fecal odor, severe abdominal pain with ascites, sudden change in LOC, seizure activity.

Interventions

  • Ice chips
  • Clear fluids
  • Ginger ale
  • Dry toast or crackers
  • Meticulous attention to oral care
  • Keep air and room fresh; eliminate strong odors
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

When did it begin? 
How long does it last? 
How often does it occur?
Is there more than one pain site? If so assess each site individually. Employ the concept of Total Pain

What brings it on? 
What makes it better? 
What makes it worse?

Is there a specific time of day that the pain is worse? 
If yes, explain.

What does it feel like? Describe it? 
If unable to describe, ask if the pain is sharp, dull, aching, stabbing, shooting, burning, tingling, or do they experience pins and needles?

Where is it? 
Does it spread anywhere? 
Describe the location as specifically as possible.

How severe is this symptom?
0 (none) – 10 (severe)
Right now? At worst? On average? 
How distressing is the symptom?

Are there any other symptom(s)? 
If yes, explain.

Current medications/treatments? 
Medications taken in the past 24hrs?
How effective are these? 
What have you tried in the past?

When was the last dose of analgesic taken? 
How many breakthrough doses taken?

Are non-prescription treatments, herbal remedies, or traditional healing practices being used? 
How effective are these? Any side effects? 
What was tried in the past? 
Any concerns about side effects or cost?

Caller’s thoughts on cause for what is happening? 
What is most concerning?
How is it affecting family?
Any compromises has to be made because of the pain (decreasing activities, enduring side effects)?

Overall goals to keep in mind while managing this symptom? 
Acceptable level for this symptom (0-10)? 
Are there any beliefs, views or feelings about this symptom that are important to keep in mind?

recommendations.content:
Goals of Care: If symptom cannot be managed, is client and family open to going to hospital for further investigation and/or treatment?

It is important to try and identify the possible underlying etiology prior to making any recommendations. Interventions will then be based on assessment and goals of care.

Emergency situations requiring possible transfer to acute care: Spinal cord compression, bone fracture or impending fracture of weight-bearing bone d/t metastasis etc., infection/abscess, obstructed or perforated viscus, an ischemic process, or superior vena cava obstruction.

  • Massage, positioning, application heat/ cold. Note: use with caution with frail elderly
  • Relaxation, meditation
  • Education for client/family regards expected side effects and/or misunderstandings about regular dosing or breakthrough dosing, fears about opioids (addiction etc.).

assessment_questions.question:
When did the symptom begin?
How long does it last? 
How often does it occur?

What makes it better? 
What makes it worse?
Any new medications or treatments? If yes, explain.

Physical: Pain, constipation (last BM), bladder retention (last voiding) hypoxia (breathing rates and pattern, SOB etc), infection (fever), organ failure (cognition etc), when did the client last eat/drink?
Medication: Opioid-induced neurotoxicity – what medications is the client taking? Recent Dexamethasone order?
Psychosocial: Personal suffering, existential anguish, interpersonal conflict, worry, grief, spiritual distress
Neurologic/Other: Delirium of any cause, history of dementia, anxiety disorder, psychosis etc.

Imminently Dying (Terminal Restlessness): 
Select present combinations with altered and declining state of consciousness.
Are there any other symptoms that you are noticing such as muscle twitching, jerking, fidgeting, yelling, moaning, tossing and turning, crying, despondent etc.?

How distressing is this symptom?
0 (no distress) – 10 (extremely distressing)
Is there a certain time of day that symptom(s) worsen? If yes, explain.

Is there a current plan in place for restlessness/anxiety/agitation? 
If yes, explain.

Current medications/treatments? 
Medications taken in the past 24hrs?
How effective are these? 
What have you tried in the past?

Caller’s thoughts on cause for what is happening? 
What is most concerning?
How is it affecting family?

Overall goals to keep in mind while managing this symptom? 
Acceptable level for this symptom (0-10)? 
Are there any beliefs, views or feelings about this symptom that are important to keep in mind?

recommendations.content:
Identify the possible underlying etiology prior to making any recommendations. E.g. bladder retention, constipation, opioid neuro-toxicity, pain, etc.

Recommendations will be based on Goals of Care and family/caregiver’s ability to manage care in the home.

Goals of Care: If symptom cannot be managed, would the client/family consider going to hospital for further investigation and/or treatment?

If delirium is suspected:
This may be reversible with investigation and treatment dependant on Goals of Care. Refer to Delirium Protocol.

If terminal restlessness is suspected:

  • Review client’s care plan for restlessness/agitation
  • Review care plan for EOL planning

Ensure the following:

  • Caregiver is with client at all times
  • Timely administration of medication if ordered and able to administer
  • Comfort and gentle reassurance and repeated reorientation, ambient lighting according to time of day, speak quietly, reduce stimulation, play music, etc.
  • Limit number of visitor especially at one time
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

recommendations.content: Review medications with caregiver. Advise which medications to give based on current orders.

recommendations.content:
Review medications with caregiver. Advise which medications to give based on current orders.

Myoclonus/twitching

  • Opioid-induced myoclonus is often misinterpreted as seizure activity
  • Impaired excretion of opioids
  • Most prevalent in renal impairment with morphine, codeine, meperidine and, to a lesser extent, hydromorphone.
  • Liver impairment
  • Possible drug causes and/or interactions
  • Dehydration may be a contributing factor
recommendations.title: Pharmaceutical Interventions

recommendations.content:
Goals of Care: If symptom cannot be managed, would the client/family consider going to hospital for further investigation and/or treatment of symptom?

Background

  • Seizures may be caused by primary or metastatic brain tumours
  • Metabolic causes: hypoglycemia (most common metabolic cause), hyperglycemia, hyponatremia, renal or hepatic failure, and hypercalcemia
  • Terminal delirium can also be misinterpreted as seizure activity and/or myoclonus
  • Other causes may include: stroke, sepsis or late onset epilepsy

Consider twitching/myoclonus vs seizure activity

  • Identifying the possible underlying etiology of seizure vs myoclonus/twitching is essential in order to make recommendations
  • Consider that if this is the client’s first seizure experience, with no plan in place and the seizure activity is not stopping, that a seizure is a medical emergency

Review client’s care plan if one in place for seizure activity

  • Primary focus is on safety during and after seizures
  • Do not attempt to restrain the client
  • Loosen tight clothing around the neck
  • Do not try to force anything into the client’s mouth
  • Do not give any fluids or food by mouth until the client has fully recovered consciousness
  • When the seizure stops, turn the client onto his/her side until fully alert. Expect a period of sleepiness after the seizure
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

0 (no pain) – 10 (severe)

How distressing is the symptom?
Are there any other symptom(s) that accompany this symptom (e.g., pain, dyspnea, anxiety)? Ask about soaked bed linen, number of saturated gauzes etc.

Is there a current plan in place for bleeding? 
If yes, explain.

Current medications/treatments? 
Medications taken in the past 24hrs?
How effective are these? 
What have you tried in the past?

Are there dressing supplies in the home?
Have any special dressings been used to absorb bleeding?

Caller’s thoughts on cause for what is happening?

Overall goals to keep in mind while managing this symptom?

recommendations.content:
Depending on Goals of Care it may be possible to manage a severe bleed in the home and may not necessarily require a transfer to acute care.
If symptom cannot be managed, would the client/family consider going to hospital for further investigation and/or treatment?

Emergencies
Catastrophic, massive bleeding requires urgent attention because of its dramatic and traumatic clinical presentation and the profound distress it causes to clients, families and caregivers. While a catastrophic bleed is not painful for the client, it is often described as a terrifying experience for the client and family/caregiver. This affects not only the family’s experience at the time of death but runs the risk of affecting the nature of their grief and bereavement.

Review client’s care plan if one in place for severe bleeding

  • Ensure caregiver is with client at all times
  • Timely administration of medication if ordered and able to administer
  • Local direct pressure may be appropriate for an external wound
  • Comfort and reassure client
  • Maintain airway and positioning
  • Cover client with dark towels or sheets
  • Apply extra blankets for warmth
recommendations.title: Non-Pharmaceutical Interventions

plans.plan: After hours nurse to follow-up in 30 to 60 minutes if symptom management
Home care nurse to follow-up next morning with visit
Reach out for medical support (e.g. MRP)
Recommend going to UPCC (Urgent Primary Care Center)* if appropriate and unable to manage symptoms at home and if ambulatory and within client’s goals of care
plans.details: Before 10pm: downtown Vancouver & Lonsdale North Vancouver

plans.plan: Recommend calling 911 or going to emergency department if unable to manage symptoms at home and within client’s goals of care
